items.title: Add django-nose and nose status to the README
items.body:
The [nose docs](https://nose.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) have this note:

> Nose has been in maintenance mode for the past several years and will likely cease without a new person/team to take over maintainership. New projects should consider using [Nose2](https://github.com/nose-devs/nose2), [py.test](http://pytest.org/), or just plain unittest/unittest2.

I think this project should have a similar note about the status of ``django-nose``.

Personally, I no longer use ``django-nose`` on my work projects (I'm a happy convert to [pytest](http://pytest.org/)), which means I do not have a working project for testing the project, finding issues, and confirming changes. In addition, I've had less and less time and energy for the work of open source maintenance. I'm sorry that this has impacted this project. 

My hope with migrating to jazzband is that it would be easier for the users of the project to identify themselves and take over maintenance. I think a clear statement in the project README would help this along.

Here's my first draft:

# Note to users:

[Nose](https://nose.readthedocs.io/en/latest/) has been in maintenance mode since at least 2015. `django-nose` is in maintenance mode as well, and the sole maintainer is no longer an active user. See [https://jazzband.co](jazzband.co) to learn how `django-nose` is maintained and how you can help. New projects should consider using [py.test](http://pytest.org/), or [unittest](https://docs.python.org/3/library/unittest.html) with the [Django testing framework](https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/3.1/topics/testing/).


This only happens on Django 2.X, and only when django-nose's test runner is enabled. Removing the line
```
TEST_RUNNER = 'django_nose.NoseTestSuiteRunner'
```
from settings.py fixes the issue.

These errors also don't seem to come up at all outside of unit testing (which I guess makes sense if the issue is somehow related to django-nose).

Here is an example test from the test.py file:
```python
from django.test import TestCase
from django.urls import reverse
from huntserver import models

def get_and_check_page(test, page, code, args={}):
    response = test.client.get(reverse(page, kwargs=args))
    test.assertEqual(response.status_code, code)
    return response

class InfoTests(TestCase):
    fixtures = ["basic_hunt"]

    def test_index(self):
        "Test the index page"
        response = get_and_check_page(self, 'huntserver:index', 200)
        self.assertTrue(isinstance(response.context['curr_hunt'], models.Hunt))
```

I'm seeing these issues locally locally on Debian 9 (Stretch), but it also seems to fail in the same way on travis-ci (Which appears to be ubuntu 16.04): https://travis-ci.org/dlareau/puzzlehunt_server/builds/636368209

```
mysql  Ver 15.1 Distrib 10.1.41-MariaDB, for debian-linux-gnu (x86_64) using readline 5.2
```

Database settings:
```

    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.mysql',
        'NAME': 'puzzlehunt_db',
        'HOST': 'localhost',
        'PORT': '3306',
        'USER': 'hunt',
        'PASSWORD': 'NotMyRealMysqlPassword',
        'OPTIONS': {'charset': 'utf8mb4'},
    }
}
```

I've looked into each of the listed errors (the Transaction issue/the "OperationalError"). A lot of what I found searching keywords wasn't applicable, though I tried many of the solutions anyway to no avail.

If it is relevant, the source code for my whole project can be found here: https://github.com/dlareau/puzzlehunt_server/tree/development

Let me know if there is any other info I can provide.

Thanks for any help!

items.body:
This issue tracks the implementation of the [Jazzband guidelines](https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines) for the project [django-nose](https://github.com/jazzband/django-nose) It was initiated by @jwhitlock who was automatically assigned in addition to the [Jazzband roadies](https://jazzband.co/roadies). See the [TODO list](#todos) below for the generally required tasks, but feel free to update it in case the project requires it. Feel free to ping a [Jazzband roadie](https://jazzband.co/roadies) if you have any question. ## TODOs - [x] Fix all links in the docs (and README file etc) from old to new repo - [x] Add the [Jazzband badge](https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines#badges) to the `README` file - [x] Add the [Jazzband contributing guideline](https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines#contributing-guidelines) to the `CONTRIBUTING.md` file - [x] Check if continuous testing works (e.g. [Travis-CI](https://travis-ci.org/), [CircleCI](https://circleci.com), [AppVeyor](https://www.appveyor.com), etc) - [x] Check if test coverage services work (e.g. [Coveralls](https://coveralls.io), [Codecov](https://codecov.io), etc) - [x] Add `jazzband` account to [PyPI](https://pypi.org/) project as maintainer role (e.g. URL: `https://pypi.org/manage/project//collaboration/`) - [x] Add `jazzband-bot` as maintainer to the [Read the Docs](https://readthedocs.org/) project (URL: `https://readthedocs.org/dashboard//users/`) - [x] Fix project URL in [GitHub project](https://github.com/jazzband/django-nose) description - [x] Review project if other services are used and port them to Jazzband - [x] Decide who is project lead for the project (if at all) and setup CI for it if needed ## Project details

items.title: Oracle backend issue with test settings
items.body:
## DESIRED BEHAVIOR

*All* test settings, rather than just the database name, will be copied for oracle tests, because a schema is the main way to vary the tests.   This is also desirable as an option for PostgreSQL.

`REUSE_DB` will default to off for Oracle, because Oracle has the `CREATE_DB` and `CREATE_USER` options.

## ACTUAL BEHAVIOR

Only the ``NAME`` of the Oracle connection is copied, meaning that our TNS names must map 1-to-1 with projects, preventing our previous environment from working.

When I run my tests using Oracle backend, it runs against the main database rather than the test database:

```python
DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.oracle',
        'NAME': 'MEDPLUS_DEV',
        'USER': _schema,
        'PASSWORD': _password,
        'HOST': '',
        'PORT': '',
        'TEST': {
            'CREATE_DB': False,
            'CREATE_USER': False,
            'USER': _test_schema,
            'NAME': 'MEDPLUS_DEV',
            'PASSWORD': _test_password,
        },
    }
}
```

When I run the test --pdb, I can verify that the current schema shows that I'm still in the main development schema, rather than the test schema:

```
$ ./manage.py test mplusmon.tests.test_tags --pdb                                                                                                               
nosetests mplusmon.tests.test_tags --rednose --with-xunit --xunit-file C:\Users\davisda4\workspace\mplusmonitor\reports\python-unit-tests.xml --with-coverage --
cover-package mplusmon,ng_loader,conf --pdb --verbosity=1                                                                                                       
....> c:\tools\python\3.5\lib\unittest\case.py(813)_baseAssertEqual()                                                                                           
-> raise self.failureException(msg)                                                                                                                             
(Pdb) up                                                                                                                                                        
> c:\tools\python\3.5\lib\unittest\case.py(820)assertEqual()                                                                                                    
-> assertion_func(first, second, msg=msg)                                                                                                                       
(Pdb) up                                                                                                                                                        
> c:\users\davisda4\workspace\mplusmonitor\mplusmon\tests\test_tags.py(30)test_tags_list()                                                                      
-> self.assertEqual(len(taglist), 2)                                                                                                                            
(Pdb) from django.db import connection                                                                                                                          
(Pdb) cursor = connection.cursor()                                                                                                                              
(Pdb) cursor.execute("SELECT sys_context('userenv', 'current_schema') from dual;")                                                                              
<cx_Oracle.Cursor on <cx_Oracle.Connection to mplusmon_dev@MEDPLUS_DEV>>                                                                                        
(Pdb) for row in cursor: print(row)                                                                                                                             
('MPLUSMON_DEV',)                                                                                                                                               
(Pdb)                                                                                                                                                           
```

## WORKAROUND

- Use earlier version of django-nose
- Write our own TestSuiteRunner that extends TestSuiteRunner
- Change the settings to use the 'django_nose.BasicNoseRunner':

```python
TEST_RUNNER = 'django_nose.BasicNoseRunner'
```

`python manage.py test tests.views.test_module_view`

items.title: Move project to jazzband
items.body:
[Jazzband](https://jazzband.co) is a project to share responsibility for administration of open source projects. django-nose is a good candidate because:
1. The project is mature and widely used. It is part of the workflow of mature projects, and is often picked because it is the "boring" choice.
2. Community attention is on [py.test](http://pytest.org/latest/), which is gaining plugins and features. This is reflected in the bug-to-PR ratio in the issue tracker (many bug reports, fewer PRs).
3. The project has been maintained by Mozilla developers. Out of the "Maintainer" list in AUTHORS.rst, only one (me) is actually active. Mozilla projects are moving away from django-nose, which means that work will have to move to nights and weekends, for even less attention and slower releases.
4. Built-in features like `REUSE_DB=1` are [flaky](https://github.com/django-nose/django-nose/milestones/Fix%20REUSE_DB=1) and not used by everyone. This means that patches work for some people and not for others. These features require the collaboration of the users of the features, and rapid iteration through possible code changes to get to a shared solution.  Since I don't use these optional features, I can't really judge the PRs we do get.

By moving to jazzband, we'll make it easier for contributors to merge changes and make official releases. In the best case, this will spark some additional contribution to fix long broken features. In the worst case, the people that really need support for the latest Django will be able to publish a compatible version.

To move to jazzband, we'll have to follow the [guidelines](https://jazzband.co/about/guidelines). I think we're pretty close, but will need some changes, such as updating our `CONTRIBUTING.rst`.

I'm looking for feedback from existing maintainers ( @jbalogh , @erikrose, @jsocol, @robhudson ), as well as those who rely on django-nose. If you stay silent, I'm assuming you are OK with the changes needed.

items.title: Test databases are created in an inconsistent order
items.body:
With the django-nose test runner, I'm unable to specify the order that my databases are created in, causing all of my tests to randomly fail when they are created out of order, due to tables not existing. With the default Django test runner, the default database is always created first, and you are able to specify dependencies for others, as seen here: https://docs.djangoproject.com/en/1.9/topics/testing/advanced/#controlling-creation-order-for-test-databases

This is all handled by the `dependency_ordered()` method in `django/test/runner.py` (https://github.com/django/django/blob/master/django/test/runner.py#L555). Is there any chance of using this same solution in the NoseTestSuiteRunner?

With Django 1.7.10 installed, I ran:

``` bash
pip install -U django-nose
```

and it also updated Django to 1.8.5 because it's in `install_requires` in `setup.py`. This seems logical, but can have serious unintended consequences, which is why I usually avoid listing Django itself as an actual install dependency.

items.title: Jasmine-style "focused" test running
items.body:
I've been using [Jasmine](http://jasmine.github.io/) recently, and I've found it does a tonne of things really nicely. One of those is the ability to run ["focussed tests"](http://jasmine.github.io/2.1/focused_specs.html) where only a single test or a subset of tests actually run. This works really nice when debugging an individual test as you don't need to plow through the entire suite to just get the resolution of one.

Clearly we can already do this sort of thing with Django-nose but calling an individual TestCase or test from the command line, but this takes time. For example

`python manage.py test app.tests.test_something:FooTestCase.test_bar_works`

is quite a hassle to write, and it's my opinion that a simpler option would be far more useful. I'm not sure how this would apply to Python, perhaps through the use of a decorator `@focused` which would add the method or test case to a register of white-listed tests to run.

I'd be happy to take a look at this at some point if it piques anyone's interest.

items.title: Release 1.4
items.body:
A 1.4 release is needed for Django 1.8 compatibility.

Includes PRs
- #185 - Django 1.8 compatibility
- #188 - Add contribute.json
- #187 - Support --testrunner
- #194 - Add 1.8 to test matrix
- #196 - Convert nose optparse options to argparse 

Any other PRs that should be included?

Django legacy transaction management deprecated

items.title: Awkward PEP8’ed assertion names
items.body:
`django_nose.tools` looks up assert functions inside `TransactionTestCase`, and provide PEP8-compatible versions of them. The mangling works for most of the names, but with some the end results are awkward. Examples:
- `assertJSONEqual` → `assert_j_s_o_n_equal`
- `assertInHTML` → `assert_in_h_t_m_l`
- `assertXMLEqual` → `assert_x_m_l_equal`

Any suggestions on this? I’d be happy to submit a pull request if there’s a way to deal with these cases. Or would it be better to just provide some manual name mapping for acronyms?

items.title: Needs update to work with Django 1.8
items.body:
As of a few days ago, line 23 of runner.py fails with the master branch of Django, due to django/django#3899

```
    from django.db.backends.creation import BaseDatabaseCreation
```

needs to change to:

```
    from django.db.backends.base.creation import BaseDatabaseCreation
```

items.title: Python 3.4 changes in "types.MethodType" affect to REUSE_DB option
items.body:
Trying to set REUSE_DB=1 under Python 3.4 error raised:

> File "lib/python3.4/site-packages/django_nose/runner.py", line 395, in setup_databases
>     _skip_create_test_db, creation, creation.__class__)
> TypeError: method expected 2 arguments, got 3

Since MethodType takes only two arguments and third argument `creation.__class__` no longer needs in this case.

items.title: builds broken for latest django (1.8)
items.body:
The trunk builds are broken because of django/django@8568638

The option parser was changed to argparse, and an optparse compatability layer was introduced. I don't believe the hackety way of "option renaming" can be done as it is right now.

See:
https://github.com/django-nose/django-nose/blob/bfeb0983cce5d78c88a6099057a746c795574fa3/django_nose/runner.py#L102

items.title: django-nose last release is one year old, could we release the next version ASAP?
incompatiblity with profile plugin
items.body:
Both use prepareTest to do some initialization.

prepareTest by design only calls it on the first plugin it finds it on that returns a truth value and then stops processing any further plugins.

django_nose uses this hook to setup the database.  Where else could it do that in the nose plugin architecture?

items.title: Test client is not initialized in FastFixtureTestCase
items.body:
TransactionTestCase initializes the Django test client in _pre_setup(). Since that 
is intentionally not called by FastFixtureTestCase, the test client never gets
initialized, making FastFixtureTestCase break many tests when replacing 
Django's test case.

items.title: Using south and coverage with django_nose results in models have incorrect coverage report.
items.body:
Running django_nose using `--with-coverage`, and with south installed, results in incorrect coverage reporting. This is particularly a problem for model.py, but probably messes with declarative statements in other modules too.

This seems to be because south gets to do it's magic before plugins are run, so coverage isn't initialized:

``` python
# Django < 1.2 compatibility
test_runner = settings.TEST_RUNNER
if test_runner.endswith('run_tests') or test_runner.endswith('run_gis_tests'):
    import warnings
    warnings.warn(
        'Use `django_nose.NoseTestSuiteRunner` instead of `%s`' % test_runner,
        DeprecationWarning)


TestRunner = get_runner(settings)
```

Not sure if this is just a limitation one has to deal with (I couldn't think of an obvious fix to submit as a patch), but I wanted to at least report it. I spent a fair while trying to work out why my models.py were reporting only 10% coverage and this'll hopefully be easy to search for.

As mentioned in other related coverage issues, the workaround is:

```
coverage run ./manage.py test
```

items.title: REUSE_DB + TEST_NAME + Table Sync
items.body:
Hi all. I'm going to do the best I can to explain the issue I'm having, which I can verify is present in the master branch of django-nose, as well as the stable release.

What I'm trying to do is run my tests against a PostgreSQL database that already exists, and whose purpose is solely to run unit tests. EG: I've created a database on a remote host that is to be used exclusively for unit tests.

To this end, I've used Django's TEST_NAME key in the DATABASES dict, which allows me to override the default test database name to a name of my choosing.

So my configuration looks something like:

``` python
DATABASES = {
    'default': {
        'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.postgresql_psycopg2',
        'NAME': 'blah', # production db name
        'USER': 'blah',
        'PASSWORD': 'blah',
        'HOST': 'blah',
        'PORT': 'blah', 
        'TEST_NAME': 'specialtestdbname',
    }
}}}}
```

What's happening, however, when I run `REUSE_DB=1 python manage.py test` (after hooking up the NoseTestSuiteRunner), is that django-nose does NOT create the tables in my database, 'specialtestdbname'. Instead, it tries to run the tests against the database without first creating the necessary tables.

What I'd like to see happen is:
- django-nose recognize that my database exists, and therefore not try to create it (this works right now).
- django-nose to create all my tables (it is not doing this)
- django-nose to run my tests
- django-nose to destroy all my tables (but not the database!)

Does that make sense? I think this would be pretty awesome.

Thank you.

I have 2 main types of tests classes, one using fixtures with the FastFixtureTestCase and one not. The nose test runner seems to blow up when switching between them, in the tearDownClass method.

I have created some test users and 1 group, which are loaded from the fixtures, but the main thing is that I'm not sure why they aren't deleting properly! 

My current fix, is to force delete any existing User/Group/Permissions before the fixtures get unloaded, which does what I want and lets the tests finish correctly.

```
@classmethod
def tearDownClass(cls):
    print 'class tear down'
    User.objects.all().delete()
    Group.objects.all().delete()
    Permission.objects.all().delete()
    super(SMTest, cls).tearDownClass()
```

It seems like you are forcing foreign key checks here: https://github.com/jbalogh/django-nose/blob/master/django_nose/testcases.py#L104

Any thoughts on making that an option? Or figuring out what my data issue is?

items.title: Dirty DB
items.body:
I am having `IntegrityError` problems when `REUSE_DB` is activated.
It happens because my tests try to **recreate instances** already existent in database, **created on earlier runs**.

``` ruby
IntegrityError: duplicate key value violates unique constraint "auth_user_username_key"
```

I believe that **every time** we run our tests, it **should found the same** enviroment.
Repeting tests, must repeat results.
Nowadays, it is not what is happening, because it **is accumulating dirt** on database.

So, I propose we do a **rollback** after tests run. Not after each test, as proposed on #20 (would be very slower, and can be done overiding TestCase), but **after all tests are done**.

I am new with `nose` and `django-nose`, so I appreciate to know your ideas.

items.title: Django tests do not get run
items.body:
When running the nose testrunner, it seems not to bother with tests outside of the project folder. Hence, it doesn't run a lot of tests that Django's default test runner _does_ run.

This _might_ just be a configuration issue, allthough I've followed the README closely. Also, it seems as though there are no similar issues already on GH. The issue _might_ be related to Django 1.4.

To replicate the issue:
- Clone [this testing gist](https://gist.github.com/3141710)
- Make a VirtualEnv with all packages in `requirements.txt` available
- Running `python manage.py test` yields the following output:
  
  ```
  Creating test database for alias 'default'...
  .......................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................................s........................................................................
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Ran 416 tests in 18.587s
  
  OK (skipped=1)
  Destroying test database for alias 'default'...
  ```
- Running the tests with nose using `python manage.py test --settings=nosebleed.settings_nose` yields the following:
  
  ```
  Creating test database for alias 'default'...
  
  ----------------------------------------------------------------------
  Ran 0 tests in 0.000s
  
  OK
  Destroying test database for alias 'default'...
  ```

The same issue occurs when running 83869cc5a1ea53e5b83e6db1f76cb104e31d6f38 from GitHub.

items.title: --with-profile getting no results (“0 function calls”)
items.body:
I'm trying to diagnose some slow running unit tests, but I'm not having any luck getting the profiler working with django-nose. I came up with a repo case on a brand new Django project.

``` bash
django-admin.py startproject nosetest
cd nosetest/

virtualenv --no-site-packages --distribute virtualenv
source virtualenv/bin/activate
pip install django_nose

echo "
DATABASES = {
'default': {
    'ENGINE': 'django.db.backends.sqlite3',
    'NAME': ':memory',
},
}

INSTALLED_APPS = INSTALLED_APPS + ('django_nose', )

TEST_RUNNER = 'django_nose.NoseTestSuiteRunner'
" >> nosetest/settings.py

echo "
import unittest
import time

class SlowTestCase(unittest.TestCase):
def test_slow(self):
    self.assertFalse(time.sleep(1))
" > nosetest/test.py

python manage.py test --with-profile
```

This should create a new Django project in the current directory, install some dependencies in a virtualenv, create a valid settings.py and then run a new unit test.

I'm expecting to see various function calls in the output. Instead, I'm getting the following:

``` bash
nosetests --verbosity 1 --with-profile
Creating test database for alias 'default'...
.
     0 function calls in 0.000 seconds

Ordered by: cumulative time

ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
    0    0.000             0.000          profile:0(profiler)


----------------------------------------------------------------------
Ran 1 test in 1.002s

OK
Destroying test database for alias 'default'...
```

I have tried the cProfiler with nose-cprof, but that is giving similar results. Can anyone get this same project working, or point me to another solution for profiling this test?

items.title: Path issues, dependent on global test case run vs specific test module run
items.body:
The setup for my current project is that the project root directory has a certain name, and there is a directory within the root, of the same name, which in turn contains all the app directories. So:

/path/to/project_name/
/path/to/project_name/project_name/
/path/to/project_name/project_name/app_1/
/path/to/project_name/project_name/app_2/
/path/to/project_name/project_name/app_3/

And so on. When I run:

REUSE_DB=1 ./manage.py test

It passes many tests, but fails whenever the test case calls reverse():

```
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 476, in reverse
  return iri_to_uri(resolver._reverse_with_prefix(view, prefix, *args, **kwargs))
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 363, in _reverse_with_prefix
  possibilities = self.reverse_dict.getlist(lookup_view)
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 276, in reverse_dict
  self._populate()
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 242, in _populate
  for pattern in reversed(self.url_patterns):
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 328, in url_patterns
  patterns = getattr(self.urlconf_module, "urlpatterns", self.urlconf_module)
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/core/urlresolvers.py", line 323, in urlconf_module
  self._urlconf_module = import_module(self.urlconf_name)
File "<virtual_env_path>/local/lib/python2.7/site-packages/django/utils/importlib.py", line 41, in import_module
  __import__(name)

ImportError: No module named urls
```

Doing some debugging, it looks like it's failing when trying to import "project_name.urls". I realized that it was getting confused, because /path/to/project_name/urls.py doesn't exist, but /path/to/project_name/project_name/urls.py does. If I rename the first "project_name" directory (which my teammates prefer not to do), it fixes it:

/path/to/blah/project_name/app_1
/path/to/blah/project_name/urls.py

And so forth.

Interestingly, the problem ALSO goes away (without renaming anything) when I run a specific test module:

REUSE_DB=1 ./manage.py test project_name.app_1.tests

I tried looking at the offending __import__ line. The name it's importing, and the sys.path at that point, are identical. Even in the sense of basic Python, I don't understand how this is possible, but maybe there's something I don't understand about the importing process.

Is this a bug in Django Nose? In either case, is there something else I could try with the sys.path that I'm missing?

Thanks.

items.title: Don't set up DB if no tests use it
items.body: Set up the DB only if a test that's a subclass of TransactionTestCase is among the selected tests (or something). That can save a bunch of time when not using REUSE_DB.

items.title: Have 1 REUSE_DB advisory message, not 6
items.body:
On running the tests without REUSE_DB, you get a message for each DB:

```
To reuse old database "test_such_and_such" for speed, set env var REUSE_DB=1.
To reuse old database "test_such_and_such2" for speed, set env var REUSE_DB=1.
```

This can cause rather a lot of noise if you have a lot of DBs. Let's have a single message.

items.title: publish 1.1 version to pypi
Incompatible with TransactionTestCase
items.body: Django's TransactionTestCase flushes the DB on _fixture_setup—that is, before each test. We somehow defeat that.

items.title: Unable to determine if django_nose is installed

milestone.description: Stuff we have to wait until we can break backward compatibility to do

items.body:
I want to include `django_nose` in the project settings only if it is installed:

``` python
try:
    import django_nose
    INSTALLED_APPS += ['django_nose']
    TEST_RUNNER = 'django_nose.NoseTestSuiteRunner'
except ImportError:
    pass
```

I expected that to work, but I get an `ImportError: Settings cannot be imported ...` exception. The problem is that `django_nose/__init__.py` imports everything from `django_nose/runner.py`, which in turn imports Django and breaks.

As last resort I could check the ImportError message itself, but I hope there is a cleaner solution to this.

items.title: Claify in documentation that at least Django 1.1 is required
items.body: `django_nose` definitely doesn't run on Django 1.0 (for one thing, it uses `django.test.utils.get_runner` which was [only added](https://code.djangoproject.com/ticket/10165) after 1.0) -- could the "Older Versions of Django" include that info? Might save someone else a little time.

project.utils.cache_util      61     16    74%   1-11, 32, 40, 45, 52, 56, 64, 75, 78, 81, 84, 93

All those missing are either imports or class definitions or class methods.

Any ideas?

items.body:

```
$ ./manage.py test -p --verbosity 2
```

items.title: Possible to make optional for the project?
items.body:
I have a project for which I would like to use django-nose for testing, but I would prefer not to require django-nose to be present for the app itself to run. (For example, I don't want production installations of our product to require django-nose - they won't be running unit tests and I'd like to minimize what they have to install). I can't just test if django-nose is importable in settings.py, because when it tries to import it there is an Import Error:

ImportError: Settings cannot be imported, because environment variable DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE is undefined.

Is this currently possible?

items.title: Inconsistent behavior when running tests
items.body:
I have two django projects and `django-nose` seems to behave differently with each one.

The first project is smaller. I run

```
$ python manage.py test app1 app2 app3
```

And only the tests in those apps are run. It works perfectly. It's amazingly fast and flawless.

However, the other project, which is a lot bigger has problems. It seems to ignore my requests to only test certain app. It instead tests applications that are in my `INSTALLED_APPS` and beyond. For example, it will run Sentry's tests without being asked to.  I read in [34](https://github.com/jbalogh/django-nose/issues/34) that it looks at everything on the Python path. Why is that? Why does it work in the first app?

Thanks!

items.title: Supporting standalone test runner
items.body:
This is more of a draft idea, and I'm not entirely sure how we should approach it, but it'd be nice if we could somehow support a standalone test runner a bit easier.

Right now I end up with something containing, at minimum, the following::

```
#!/usr/bin/env python
import sys
import os, os.path
from optparse import OptionParser

from django.conf import settings

parent = os.path.dirname(os.path.abspath(__file__))
sys.path.insert(0, parent)

if 'DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE' not in os.environ:
    os.environ['DJANGO_SETTINGS_MODULE'] = 'disqus.conf.settings.test'

from django_nose import NoseTestSuiteRunner

def runtests(*test_args, **kwargs):
    if 'south' in settings.INSTALLED_APPS:
        from south.management.commands import patch_for_test_db_setup
        patch_for_test_db_setup()

    test_runner = NoseTestSuiteRunner(**kwargs)

    failures = test_runner.run_tests(test_args)
    sys.exit(failures)

if __name__ == '__main__':
    parser = OptionParser()
    parser.add_option('--verbosity', dest='verbosity', action='store', default=1, type=int)
    parser.add_options(NoseTestSuiteRunner.options)
    (options, args) = parser.parse_args()

    if not args:
        args = ['tests', 'disqus']

    runtests(*args, **options.__dict__)
```
